required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Relation Between Rectus Femoris Muscle Tension and Hamstring Strength and Activity in Healthy Sprinters
clinical_study.official_title: Relation Between Rectus Femoris Muscle Tension and Hamstring Strength and Activity in Healthy Sprinters

brief_summary.textblock:
An open-label, single-group, control, pretest-posttest clinical trial is going to be conducted, with 16 healthy sprinters. Rectus femoris length and hamstring strength and electromyography is going to be assessed at baseline, after 10 minutes control and after an static rectus femoris stretching technique.
The main objective is to register if an increase in rectus femoris stretching Range of Motion, increases hamstring strength and activity due to their antagonic relationship and their relation with pelvic tilt.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Inmediate after intervention; up to 10 minutes
primary_outcome.description: Knee flexion range of motion with inclinometer

primary_outcome.time_frame: Inmediate after intervention; up to 10 minutes
Inmediate after intervention; up to 10 minutes

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Inmediate after intervention; up to 10 minutes
Inmediate after intervention; up to 10 minutes
Inmediate after intervention; up to 10 minutes

arm_group.description: Rectus femoris static stretching during 90' (with three hold-relax progressions until final ROM)

intervention.description: Patient lying prone with the non-implicated leg outside the treatment table resting on the floor. Physical therapist flexes patients knee until tension is felt. In that position 5 seconds' isometric contraction is asked and physical therapist progresses in knee flexion range of motion until new tension is felt. After three contract-relax procedures physical therapist holds the range of motion for 30 seconds.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- The athletes recruited have to be under regular training and competition
- Free of any symptoms, at least 3 days training weekly for the last three years
- Give written consent
Exclusion criteria:
- Subjects who have suffered lower limb or back injuries during those last three years

overall_official.last_name: Alazne Ruiz de Escudero Zapico, PhD

patient_data.ipd_description: All individual participant data that underlie results in a publication
